The shift in Color is caused by thin film breaking. If you transmit light from the bottom, it does not interact with the top layer of the scale. but when you transmit it from the top the breaking index of a thin film on top of the scale cause destructive interfering of the EM waves of the light causing that some colors are not visible and some that are visible. As a matter of fact, the scales don't even have a color of their own, it is just the thickness of the thin film causing different colors.

I had recently watched this video and stopped her for a second to explain to her that the dust was actually little scales from the wings, and then told her everything else I could remember from the video. Nice video and beautiful imagery!  As for the wing being different colors based on where the light is coming from.. The wing appears to repel light around the yellow to blue wavelengths (mostly green).  That would indicate the wing is absorbing the rest of the color spectrum, or allowing it to pass straight through.  When you shine light on the surface facing toward you you'll see whatever light is reflected, green in this case.  When you shine light on the surface facing away from you you'll see whatever light is allowed to pass through the wing.

This leads to an interesting thought experiment.. If our eyes could only see light wavelengths in the red to yellow range would this butterfly appear to have mostly transparent wings?

I'm also curious if you were to try this experiment with a red or orange winged butterfly would light passing through appear to be blue or green? 

Also, I noticed an interesting pattern in the placement of these wing scales.  When both the upper and lower lights are illuminated it's clear that the space between the scales on one side line up with the center of the scales on the opposing side.  Basically, there seems to be a staggering effect with the scales between the two faces of the wing.  Perhaps this provides structural integrity?

The difference of colors while using different lightning is due to the fact that the color you see isn't a result of pigment but a result of reflected light from a surface with tiny brushed like pattern. So those colors are a result reflecting all the white light in a certain way so that reflect only certain light waves (colors), thus it reflects a different color when the light angle changes. It works kind of like a prism which breaks white light into a rainbow but with the difference that some reflected light waves are blocked by those tiny "brushes" so that you see only a part of the light spectrum. Such way of »coloring« can be found on other animal species, for example birds. Ducks have such feathers which are made in a similar way then butterfly wings.

When I was at Art school in Scotland, there was a huge & way expensive book in the college library with big illustrations of buttery wings from all around the world.
 One butterfly from Sth America stood out and completely wowed me, unlike most/all the others wings in the book, it did not have design like eyes or wobbly stripes etc.. but an actual picture of a twig with small leaves on it.
  Nature & evolution over countless eons had become an Artist, producing a recognizable image of something in the world.
It looked like a painting by Cezanne.. dark mottled blues and greens in the background, with cool and warm pastel colours modelling the brown multi pronged twig with small green leaves on tiny stems growing from it.
 IDK of any other example where Nature has made a 2d representation of something in such a 'sophisticated' way.

I think the four fields of the cock make up two two-digit-numbers. When Destin says in the video that it's 10:06, there is one light in the first field which counts as ten (two would be twenty, I guess). Then there are two empty fields - the two zeros of the time - and the last field has six lights on. The only thing that bothers me is that in principle it would be possible to show a time like 39:69. But I think these extra spaces are only there so that the lights can move around a bit.

I suppose the wing shows different colors because one time we look at the reflected light and the other time at the transmitted light. If both sides of the scale reflect light the same way, then the green part has already been reflected if you look through the scale. Therefore I would expect that the light seems to be more reddish since the green part of the spectrum is missing.

It also might be a warning to birds. Birds know not to eat certain butterflies and moths by their coloration, knowing that they are toxic or bad for their health. Monarch butterflies are a good example.

As a term in the science of biology, a beneficial mutation is one that ADDS information to the DNA structure. These have never been discovered before.

To give an analogy, imagine that DNA spells the word "Christmas". A beneficial mutation would be one that added information (such as a new letter, E) and incorporated that new letter with existing letters in a way that increased the complexity and purpose to "Christmastime".

All known mutations destroy, they do not add anything new.

The reason (in a nutshell) for the differing colours in the butterfly wing at the end of the video is due to the fact that the internal structure of the wing absorbs higher light frequencies (such as green and blue), but allows lower ones (like red and yellow) through. The scales however, are able to reflect the higher frequency light back out, and  in fact do so at very specific frequencies. Hence the brilliant and pure colours, in this case green. Absorption vs reflection. Different colours.

That's an awesome clock!

I have a theory for why the wings appear reddish orange or bluish green depending on where the light is coming from.

Those two colors are negatives of each other. When light hits the wing, some light passes through, and some is reflected. Naturally, the wavelengths of light that pass through will be the negative of what gets reflected away. The light that passes through is white light minus green, which got reflected back towards the light source, and visa versa.

next two rows = first digit of minutes (0)
last three rows = second digit of minutes (6)
Number of lit lights indicates value e.g. 6 lit lights means digit 6

Orange color can be interpreted as 100% of red,  50% of green and 0% of blue. To get that effect I assume that wing is 100% transparent for the red, reflects 50% of the green and totally absorbs the blue. When light goes through, red is going without absorption (100%), green is half reflected and half went through (50%) and blue is totally absorbed (0%). With the front light red goes through (away from us - 0% into the eye), green is half reflected (50% again) and blue is absorbed (0%).

Think I got it for you:
Essentially each light in its own section shows a number of the clock. For 10:06:
One light is on in the first block = 1 (from the 10)
No lights are on in the second block = 0 (from the 10)
No lights are on in the third block = 0 (from the 06)
Six lights are on in the last block = 6 (from the 06)

I'm not sure why there are 3 lights in the top row though as you would only ever need 2, my guess is that it is to keep the columns and rows in straight lines.

This moth has no color on its wings at all. The shape of the surface texture of those scales (seen through a MUCH more powerful scope) refracts and reflects light of certain wavelengths and not others, making them appear to have color. There is no pigment, no color, unlike most other living things, those scales have scales a few nanometers wide. It's why they are iridescent; as the scales move, a slightly different wavelength reflects into your eye. Now THAT'S amazing. The Sunset moth.
